Photo of The Ledbury - London, United Kingdom. Beetroot caviar
Photo of The Ledbury - London, United Kingdom. Truffle, ham and egg

93SleV8FXmrasUW7yynpbQ.text: saturday night dinner review:lovely restaurant, small, very nice staff. Can choose from 6 courses and 8 courses. we took 8 because we wanted to experience as much as we could here. we tried one regular and one vegetarian tasting menu. the food in general was very good. sometimes when you eat something really amazing you get an involuntary smile on your face, happened a couple times here. Not every dish was a success. They had a pigeon dish. Im sure some people enjoy this, but we've been to a few well known places that have prepared pigeon, and it is always a very similar preparation...tastes the same, don't really care for it. its gamey, soft in an unpleasant way, and just have had enough of this on menus. the corn puree at the center of the dish was very tasty though.there was a tomato dish with langoustine oil...tomatoes were very good...didnt taste any langoustine, but just saying it made it sound fun. looked the same as the vegetarian version of the dish.the pheasant egg dish was delicious, might have been my favorite of the night outside of dessert. aubergine....tasted like warm eggplant...was good but nothing memorablescallop...i didnt really enjoy the texture of it. felt rubbery. best scallop we ever had was at le bernardin in nyc. the ledbury scallop didnt even come close to it. cauliflower dish...was very pretty to look at...tasted good...but just tasted like cauliflower the gentleman that came over to speak with us from arizona was extremely nice and pleasant to talk to...out of all the restaurants we visited on our trip, he was the most enjoyable to speak with. some of the other staff at the other restaurants were annoying.dessert...very good. raspberry buttermilk ice cream with fresh berries...very tasty. second dish i dont even remember what it was called, but very good...pictures attached.overall we would definitely come again, and will come again in the future once the pigeon is off the menu. it was expensive but if you are making a reservation here you should know what youre getting into. you will leave very full.

jNBBBvgVfScjtXCNCbEpow.text: Michelin Two-Starred restaurant The Ledbury, London. Its like a modern french cuisine with a british touch. The art was definitely more easier to interpret and to understand than some of the french three michelin star cuisines. I enjoyed every part of the meal especially the black truffle, young deer, scallp, and lamb meat. Taste was unique yet elegant and acquired that euphoric taste.

SRv6XhFj3N5KTgOoIVKJdA.text: Interesting menu that didn't quite live up to the level I was expecting.  The food was rustic modern, on the heavier side of flavor.  The lamb was excellent.  Wine by the glass was limited.  Service was great.  Bread was divine, the perfect chewy crumb and crunchy crust.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ledbury - London, United Kingdom. Local deer
Photo of The Ledbury - London, United Kingdom. Signature dessert

sV5mnBoYod1LVNksODplQw.text: Do go!The food is well thought out and well presented.Lunch is not to be missed if you want the experience without the hefty pricetag. Service is top notch too.

tztECZorUPDXgR-3MD9m9A.text: This is consistently the most exquisitely executed, brilliantly presented food in London. 4 courses at £95 at this level is very reasonable . Each course, and all the in between bites are so full of flavour , it literally explodes onto the palate! What I appreciate too is that the portions are sensible, not too much! The wine list is comprehensive and the sommelier friendly and helpful... And that's a trait that starts at the top from Brett, the chef and owner who despite his extraordinary success is down to earth, relaxed and humble... None of that Michelin starred superiority here... It's all about the food! It's a pity to see people turn up in jeans here, the food deserves a bit more than that! I'd love to see a candle on the table too, but it doesn't distract from the incredible experience of the 'art' on the plate!

8UnGTpBsXvQ-JBEVdCxlfA.text: The restaurant sets in a quiet street corner off notting hill. amazing food and service. recommend

PIWPENGb_1FWT8WFvZatJA.text: Had dinner here Sunday night.  Nice airy yet small restaurant in a quaint neighborhood in Notting Hill.Tasting menu was $145 GBP so about $219 USD per person.  They offer 8 items.  We choose the 6 item menu as there were a couple of items on the menu I'm not fond of.The appetizers were delicious.  Melt in your mouth delicious.  The service was what you'd expect from a 2 Michelin star restaurant.  Prompt, knowledgeable and very professional.The sommelier was friendly and a perfect fit for The Ledbury.  The ONLY reason we're giving it 4 stars instead of 5 is due to the size of the portions of wine.  They're literally tasting size yet you're charged for a full glass.  They're not even a quarter of a glass.  I've never seen anything like it.  Coming from California and visiting Napa regularly we found this disappointing.I hope they revisit that as I'm positive we're not the first people to comment on this.  The wine selections were good but not worth the money if you decide to buy just a glass and not a bottleOther than that try this restaurant.  The food it wonderful.

xDU3LoZP3YVvbQ1OlXpdKA.text: Wow, I loved absolutely everything about this restaurant.  After one visit it has instantly vaulted to the tops of my "must return" list.  Everything was absolutely spectacular - the room is lovely, the food was stunning, the wine unique and delicious, and all aspects of service were tremendous.  If 6 stars were an option I would go there for The Ledbury.Let's start with the room - subtle and sophisticated, the noise level is perfect and the arrangement of tables has sufficient distance to allow you to focus on the food and your dining companions.  It also enhances the flow of service (more on that later).The food was not only delicious but extremely creative in the way it incorporated and referenced indigenous British ingredients.  If the UK had had Chefs like this years ago it would not have developed it's previously well deserved reputation for bad food and warm beer.  We can definitely put a stake in the heart of the bad food part.Our tasting menu was:* Chantilly of Oyster - Tartare of Sea Bream with Frozen English Wasabi (with all the sharpness removed from the Wasabi this was a more subtle dish than I'd expected).  That would be a good precursor for the evening - subtle and sophisticated flavors that do not hit you in the face.* White Beetroot - OMG, so delicious.  Baked in clay, the beetroot is sliced thin on the mandolin and picks up amazing flavor from the smoked eel.  The Caviar salt was a revelation and elevated the dish to amazing places.  I love beets, and this is perhaps my favorite beet dish ever.* Warm Pheasant Egg with Celeriac, Dried Ham, and Truffle.  A perfectly cooked soft egg which was (shockingly) not overwhelmed by the substantial amount of Truffle in the dish.  I often find Truffle can overwhelm a dish, but again the Chef's deft touch made this ingredient delicate and subtle.  Wonderful dish.* Roast Scallop - Blood Orange, Shellfish Cream, and Asparagus.  Scallop and Asparagus both perfectly cooked (no mean feat, especially getting a large piece of Asparagus to become so tender - I was a little worried when the dish showed up with a tree trunk sized piece of Asparagus).  But let's face it, I could eat that Shellfish Cream and Blood Orange pieces by the bowl full.  Wow.* Jowl of Pork - Hispi Cabbage, Juniper and Cracking.  Similar to pork belly the jowl had a lovely (and again delicate) flavor and an excellent crust.* Aged Pigeon - Quince, Red Leaves and Vegetables.* Passionfruit Curd - again with the subtlety.  Passionfruit is usually an ingredient that hits you over the head with tartness.  This curd was subtle and wonderfully passionfruity in its flavor.* Chocolate - Dark Chocolate Chantilly and Mint - Best chocolate/mint desert ever.  Surprisingly light and refreshing, an excellent end to the meal.While the food was amazing the service was equally spectacular.  I often find restaurants can lose points on service gaffes, but The Ledbury's service was so good I'd give them extra points on top of the amazing food.Our servers were quick to gauge our level of desire for interaction.  I saw them work with each table differently, so clearly there is not just one script but rather an adroit staff.  They quickly ascertained we were foodie types and we had a running dialogue with our main server and the sommelier on the food and comparisons to other places we've dined.  Clearly a knowledgeable and passionate staff.  Everything arrived perfectly, with little fanfare, but with a perfect focus on the description to allow us to enjoy the dish.  I need to call special attention to the wine pairing and to Seamus, the sommelier.  He was a delight.  The wine pairings are composed of many small artisan producers that he had sought out (or in some cases stumbled upon).  In many cases, we not only learned about the wine we were tasting but got a good story of how he found/learned of it or what unique character produces it.  Fascinating stuff, once he learned we were an interested audience.  Plus, the wines were delicious and worked wonderfully with each of the unique dishes we were served.  Seamus was truly exemplary.  He helped take an amazing meal to the next level.I am enthralled with The Ledbury, its amazing Chef and staff.  I can't wait to return.

n6tTLnx8ixrlQjeKq_Dx2w.text: Wow, wow, wow.I scored reservations to this restaurant for my husband's birthday and when I made the reservation online I did note that we were celebrating. I'm never sure if those notes will come across but they definitely did this time. Our reservation wasn't until 9:45pm but the restaurant was kind enough to call me about 30 minutes before our reservation to tell us that our table was just about free if we wanted to come a little earlier, which we did.Upon arriving my jacket was promptly taken and I was given a hook to hang my purse on the table so that I didn't need to keep my purse on the floor. Also, there was a Happy Birthday card for my husband waiting at the table. Super classy.The entire experience was insanely good. We went with the tasting menu and the associated wine pairings for the full experience which did not disappoint at all. I had a bet going with one of the waiters that I could eat them out of their delicious bread, which I did not. But when we left, they gave us a complementary loaf of bread and their special butter with instructions for baking the next day. Hilarious! The staff is fantastic - relaxed attitudes, very friendly, very funny, and I think we kept them entertained too. Absolutely worth the price and I would not hesitate to go back - excellent way to celebrate my husband's birthday.

edcvZ2t7I3jRjPiTBAiCbQ.text: Hands down one of the most memorable dining experiences that I ever had, and I would go back in a second. I still can't believe I was able to dine in a 2 Michelin star restaurant!Everything about this restaurant is phenomenal, from the space itself to the service, and of course the food! The three of us decided to do the set lunch menu, which included the oyster, sea bass, meat, and for dessert, I had the cheese platter. I still have dreams of the cheese platter! From the very beginning, the whole team made us feel as if they were not just excited for us to be there, but excited to be a part of our dining experience. I think there is something really special about a dining staff that seems genuinely excited to experience your meal alongside you -- and that's exactly how The Ledbury team made us feel. I would go back to the Ledbury in a heartbeat (but I'm so glad I took some of it home when I snagged a bag of their compost!)

EDbdbPKItUgTJB5LkzSXyg.text: Dining at The Ledbury was a huge part of my visit to London. I went for a lunch tasting which did not disappoint. The staff were extremely friendly, personable and professional. I started my lunch with a few amuse bouches. One of them was my favorite bite of the entire meal. It was a reindeer dumpling. It had a light, soft bread-like outer shell with a warm moist filling of meat. To me it brought me to winter, in the mountains and Christmas time. It was served on a beautiful piece of food and fir tree branches. The bread served was simply delectable. There is something about the bread during tasting menus. It sort of brings you to a place of simplicity so that you can dive back into each complex dish. I had the artichoke and candy beetroot dish as my first course. I had issues with a booking so they graciously gave me an extra course and comp'd my beverages. The artichoke was a standout dish with a few different textures including sauce, gelee, and power (liquid nitrogen). The eel in the beetroot dish was distinct, so there was quite a "fishy" taste, but again well balanced. Very different from the smoked eel back home. My second course was the warm Bantam's egg. This is another must-try course. It was accompanied by truffles that melted in your mouth and dried ham and chestnuts that gave a crunch. This would be compared to a luxury breakfast dish.My third course was the gamecock which was supposedly shot the day before in Wiltshire. It first arrives smoking straight out of the oven. Not sure how they cook it but it had a distinct smokey smell. The bird was whole, feet still on in a bed of straw and fir tree branches. You get to marvel at how fresh the bird is before it is broken down for your plate. The preparation of the dish is beautiful. The additional elements on the plate make the dish truly dynamic and so cohesive at the same time. The lunch wined down with a raspberry sorbet as a palate cleanser and a light dessert. I feel like the lunch had a great balance of sophisticated cooking, nostalgic bites and local fare. I left feeling like I experienced a balance of dishes that highlighted the cuisine of the United Kingdom with a little Michelin Star twist.

hTFfxUka5X46TV3xJnPZrw.text: Presented whole prior to carving, the GF was a bit aghast, but did not let on. I was ecstatic. A huge honor, considering it was the first of the season and shot by the Chef himself, I was excited to say the leastWoodcockBrain, breast, thigh, kebab of heart, raisin Gorgeously presented, the breast was not overly gamey. Quite moist, it served medium rare. The thigh had more of a chew and ate like BBQ. The head was butterflied and obviously housed the brain, which was creamy and surprisingly sweet. Macerated raisins and water chestnuts rounded out the dish.We can't forget about the kebab of heart, lightly grilled, with great texture and a surprising sweetness.Cheese Course [15 Pound Supplement = $24.58]We also opted for the cheese course, presented by a wonderful cheesemonger from Brittany, France. Knowing we were Philly, she jokingly noted that there was no cream cheese, but went through the wide selection on offer.We ultimately decided on an all-British feature, including a wonderful burnt ash goat cheese, which was salty, creamy, and smoky. A gorgeous triple creme herbal milk's cheese. A semi-soft cheese not unlike Camembert.And last, we had a blue cheese that was herbal, yet expectedly funky. Candied smoked pecans and honey were paired with the semi-soft and blue cheese, respectively. Rustic crackers were also provided as well. Pre-Dessert Prune granite, cream custardPre-dessert was a prune granite over a cream custard. Light and refreshing - the perfect entry to dessert proper.Burnt CreamChicory, roast pear ice cream, beremeal cakeThe burnt cream ate like creme brulee without the overt vanilla flavors. The beremeal cake was moist and had a nice spice to it. Strands of pear were paired with the roast pear ice cream providing sweet, slightly tangy flavors.Hazelnut PuffsA pair of hazelnut puffs were light and perfumed, with candied hazelnuts on top to provide texture.Nitro Coconut Coconut ice cream A coconut shell housed nitro coconut ice cream within - cold, delicious, and eaten to great effect with the liquid nitrogen. Juniper Pirouettes LimeFinally, juniper pirouettes housed a tangy lime creme to provide a nice bite to end our meal.But that actually wasn't the end! GM Darren McHugh kindly offered to bring us down to the kitchen to meet Chef Austin and the brigade. Heading down the stairs, I couldn't help but snap a picture of the woodcock guarding the kitchen from above.Quiet and immaculate, it's what you would expect from a proper Michelin-starred restaurant. In addition to introducing us to his staff, Chef brought us out a final snack of chocolate and coffee crisp.Chef Austin also revealed that he had just been to L'Arpege and we both expressed our admiration for all that Chef Alain Passard has accomplished, with the simplest of ingredients.And with a final picture and handshake, our experience came to an end. Service as a whole was extremely precise, yet personable and relaxed. I couldn't rate it any higher. The meal was wonderful, with the quality of the ingredients shining through. It's safe to say that while there are more than few restaurants I'd like to try the next time I'm in London, The Ledbury will be a mainstay of each visit.

OooSgVqqg0BaB2F3i-4-rQ.text: Excellent! The Ledbury is a absolutely fantastic restaurant! The 2 Michillen stars are well deserved. The services is seemless and the atmosphere is relaxed and unpretentious. Get a reservation here if you can. Try to make it a destination when you stay in London they won't disappoint.   Now let me talk about the food...Wow! Flavor for days! All the dishes are very well thought out and the wine pairings work wonderfully with the food. I decided to go with the 4 course meal. They have 3 selections to choose from for each course. My choices were: 1st     Wild beet root baked in clay,with smoked and dryed eel. 2nd     Bantam egg, truffle, English ham(this wine pairing was the most memorable,  it was a white French wine made in a Sherry style can't remember the name just that it was awesome!) 3rd  Aged Pigeon ,with beets (so good!)4th  Chocolate things with ice cream that has the flavour of fresh herds yummy!I am recalling this from memory finishing writing this in the U.S.A . Want to say that the Ledbury  is a special place for a special occasion the whole meal for 2 with wine was 450 dollars American  $ or 300 or so pounds well worth it . I highly recommend it! Be prepared to be surprised by the food and treated great by the staff. Thank you Ledbury for a memorable meal and great exspearance! Will hope to return on my next trip to London.

gLRzaBgV4oQw5jYDjzDPuw.text: Excellent meal from start to end.  We did the lunch tasting (the shorter course) which still took 2.5 hours. Everything worked, decor, service and the food was excellent.  Every meal tasted different and used many ingredients.  My regret is not getting the cheese plate course.  I would 100% recommend this to any one who wants a great experience.  My husband and I are both vegetarians and this was excellent for that.

UgauTMhZ6i9HBSW_cPXM9A.text: Arrived London late in the day, our dinner reservation was at 9pm...exhausted but still excited to try the tasting :) since they close at 10, I felt the time between each course was being rushed and the service wasn't up to the 2 michelin Stars standard. Now on to the food....memorable dishes were the smoked fish with thinly sliced beets, made into a floral shape, truffle and warm pheasant egg, interesting textures and bold flavor profiles, compared to other tastings we had in LA.  The only dish we didn't like was the venison, maybe not used to this type of meat. Presentation was very artistic. Overall a solid 4 stars :)

c0V-EktS7r9FSz_XaGlJLQ.text: My first impression of The Ledbury: practically perfect in every way. It was not easy to make a reservation here during Christmas season, but I managed to squeeze one in just before they close. So glad that I did  and what a wonderful dinner we had!The Ledbury is located on a quiet residential street at Notting Hill. For a 2 Michelin star establishment it has a very warm and intimate ambience. It's moderately sized and very nicely decorated. I love how their lighting is soft but just bright enough, as opposed to most other fine dining restaurants where I literally have to use the candle light to read the menu, and get sleepier as the meal progresses. I never understand why this seems to be the rule for high end restaurants but I'm glad it wasn't the case at The Ledbury. I'm not going to go in detail for each dish because frankly I can't remember all the names, and it'd be an absolute disgrace to put down "that fish dish with some green sauce on the side". Check out my photos if you are interested. However, I have to say that every dish was impeccable. Beautifully presented, very well balance flavours, nice texture, and we certainly cleared every single plate. That is quite an achievement because there are 9 dishes! All the dishes came promptly, enough time in between, but never made me wonder where's the next one. Our servers were friendly and helpful. This is definitely a meal to remember and I will return at some point in the future...

dfk51FrDGS9kN8a9n-rCxQ.text: Dearest fellow diners, if you have at least a shred of moral dignity worth salvaging, please heed our advice below and opt for any other restaurant. Words cannot even come close to expressing the utmost disappointment of my three lady friends and myself. This is absolutely THE. WORST. EXPERIENCE. EVER we have had in the span of our fine dining lives. In short, we felt debased, dissatisfied and more importantly, discriminated upon. The Ledbury was mindblowingly arrogant, disrespectful, lacking and mediocre in quality - and therefore certainly way overpriced. Plus there was no effort spared at all in redeeming themselves! We travelled to this restaurant for the birthdays of two of our dear friends, to this hugely overrated Michelin restaurant. The offence we took for sure ruined the whole dining experience, but even after a cooling down period (and we ladies know about the importance of this) it remained the unanimous conclusion that we had to share our experience with you all. Service - Worst in London (to say the least, in Michelin restaurants)1. Birthday Cake IncidentThe service throughout the meal had been cursory, towards the end it was the Birthday Cake Incident that was the last straw. To set the scene, the birthday cake my friends brought was a four-layer, beautifully marbled cake. Prior to the meal specific instructions were given to put candles the right way up, so there could be no mistaking the FOUR layers. There was a clear cross-section of it, absolutely no room for error. There are two parts to the Birthday Cake Incident - first, the name of the birthday girl was completely misspelt (along the lines of Amy to Nancy). We were absolutely mortified by this but it can still be forgiven as an honest mistake. After the first mistake was rectified and the candles blown out, our cake took 20 minutes to come back and be served, and instead of the four equal and even slices we asked for, we were served 1/8ths of the cake, each in TWO layers. Who would divide a FOUR-layered cake into TWO layers each and serve cubes of it?? We plucked up our courage and still with Asian meekness, very politely asked after this, and instead of a normal apology you would expect from a Michelin-starred restaurant, the manager had the NERVE to tell us neither he nor the head chef was able to discern FOUR layers from TWO. Not a tiny twinge of guilt for ruining the night for two birthday girls - no, not the high and lofty Ledbury. The reason proffered about the small-cubes portions (disregarding our specific request to just tidily split up the cake into four portions to make life easier), was that we had a 6-course meal before. Rather my first time as a customer to have my specific request completely written off, do enlighten, Ledbury the Best Restaurant in the Whole of UK.2. Blatant, elementary mistakesEach customer is asked about any food allergies or preferences such that the kitchen can make relevant arrangements. One of us would prefer not to have foie gras, and this was sounded crystal clear in advance. The attendant assured us the menu does not consist of any foie gras. In confidence we ate what was served before us, but it soon transpired with dismay that one of the amuse bouche dishes certainly consisted of foie gras! While there was always a cursory rambling description of each dish, we thought we misheard and we trusted too much in the attendants to discover the mistake till it was too late. Whose mistake you ask? If you have a food allergy, perhaps weigh the risks.3. Disregard for OUR tablePerhaps the most infuriating experience was the unmistakeable taste of racial discrimination. We were Asians, and unlike all other tables we noticed, we were not spared any cordial chitchat during our meal. No one seemed to care about how we feel about the food or their restaurant. Further, our requests, albeit small ones such as retrieving a menu and removing a wine glass, took excessively long to be met. Until the Birthday Cake Incident towards the end, we were perfectly civil and displayed all the Asian politeness we could muster. Not reciprocated.Fair points for the brave souls out there-To be fair, the lady attendants were more normal, and we cannot say all the attendants were so very disrespectful. And they added icecream to our birthday cake cubes.The wine list and sommelier were decent, although I wish they might let us finish our glasses before refilling them because some people do prefer that? The birthday card was a nice touch but the birthday girls were not addressed

hjsBgNUS1Gn3Dt7dFboOSw.text: Incredible. I often come to 'The Ledbury' to sit back and unwind. Food is always of a high standard and the atmosphere is brilliant and peaceful. Waiters were eager to serve and carry out their jobs efficiently, as well as checking to see if you were alright. I have been here on several occasions, and I have always left with a positive experience. I will be back :)

VSSps9F2Yr4XNouK7J-0Pg.text: Pretty wonderful. 5 stars for the service we were able to book on-line for our party of 7 at a reasonable time. They were wonderful to accommodate one of our diners who was rather picky when it came to food. 5 star setting. 5 star for the very nice Sommelier who was a gracious as pretty.    As for the tasting menu, it had it's hits and misses. The menu is changing so little we can add to help you. Wonderful job with seafood and truffles.

L_OxdAQ1yIIUeKkROa4SMw.text: Quietly exquisite. That's how I'd describe my evening here. Or maybe understatedly charming is better. Or refreshingly unstuffy? Dang it, our meal here was just so downright lovely that it's hard to do it justice in words!!I loved that for such a well-known (and double Michelin-starred no less!) place, the atmosphere is just so relaxed. It's a bright but cosy dining room, and the staff are so welcoming that I felt very well taken care of right from the start (or maybe I was just overly impressed by the engraved handbag hook I was given at the table!). It's fun to people-watch here too - you can spot the regular set mingling with holidaying foodies who've read about it in a 'Best Restaurants in London' list (or yelped it ;). And then there was us, 2 wide-eyed and hungry housemates looking to celebrate a birthday by splurging on great food and wine.That's exactly what we got with the tasting menu. It changes regularly so there's little point detailing what we had, but you can tell the ingredients are high quality and each course had real substance for me - all beautifully presented without any need for the OTT flourishes that you find elsewhere. And ohh baby, the wine pairings. Do it. Don't agonise over the money at this point - if you're there, you may as well do it right!You'll need to break open the piggy bank (or three) for this one, as it's possibly the most expensive meal I've ever had. And yet, after working its very special down-to-earth magic, it's the first place in this price bracket that I can actually imagine coming back to try again. Now if only they'd halve all the prices and I really would be back once a month!

JN8_IClfDfK_K9C7tZcLnw.text: Service was wonderful and the food was delicious. They were very accommodating with our daughter and we had a thoroughly enjoyable meal. The atmosphere was very light and pleasing in the middle of a cute neighborhood. The desserts were especially memorable.

ckeIi-A-fd0pUI3-hfNWww.text: Ever eaten in a two-star Michelin restaurant in Los Angeles? What about in London? This was my chance to compare...Providence vs. Ledbury. One thing about the Ledbury is that it's tucked away in a residential area in Notting Hill. The other is that it's smart casual, so not many suits here...mostly locals. Once the Chinese arrive with cameras it'll be over...oh, that's us! :)  Pics: bit.ly/15e8G5u The decor is a relaxed, but curated vintage look: velvet embossed black drapes, chairs with muted, but unmatching textile designs, plates that change with the courses. A real sensory experience. Pics: bit.ly/131UocVWe chose the set menu $150/pp without wine. bit.ly/Yi7zBL#1 Amuse bouche. Pics: bit.ly/XPDD2I bit.ly/115Vsv6#2 #2 Chantilly of oysters with oyster tartare, cucumber and radish. Pics: bit.ly/131UvFn#3 Flame-grilled mackerel, melon radish, celeric mustard and shiso. Pics: bit.ly/141F6UQ#4 "Risotto" celeriac, new potato, smoked eel and parsley. Pics: bit.ly/110HNBy#5 Fillet seabass, brocolli stem, crab and black quinoa. Pics: bit.ly/131TMUE#6 Jowl of pork, walnut, apple and black pudding. Pics: bit.ly/103UdtG#7 Saddle of roe deer, red vegetables leaves, rhubarb and bone marrow.Pics: bit.ly/1450nNI#8 Pre-dessert. Pics: bit.ly/YAx0KV#9 #9 Brown sugar tart with poached grapes and ginger stem ice-cream. Pics: bit.ly/ZjnoYhPost-dessert. Pics: bit.ly/15e8BisSo what was my conclusion? Ledbury was pricier than Providence due to it being in London, but it was worth every penny. The dining experience was more relaxed than at Providence, yet there was no lack of dining experience and excitement to see what the next dish had in store for my tastebuds. I'd come back here. But, not so much for Providence.

Knyi32eXk-4okdpUgIFWew.text: They say that lunch is the inferior meal of fine dining. They are wrong. There is nothing inferior at The Ledbury - lunch is incredible. I often enjoy the amuse bouches even more than the apps, and this time it's true. Which is really saying something considering the quality of the apps. There's a dollop of smoked mussel cream on a nori crisp. The nori is light, and the smoky cream has such a silky texture. There's a Guinea Fowl Pate Puff, like a cream puff with meat, and a succulent crab paste with the sweetest tiniest shrimp.Fresh Hazelnuts are a lighter starter - nuts and summer fruit are always a winning combination.The Veal Tartare is so...raw. Gamey but delicate, undeniably delicious. IT come with a hunk of bread topped with beef fat which is basically just butter meaty goodness.The Native Lobster is one of the most beautiful dishes I've ever seen. I love the layers of shiitake on top, and the lobster itself is so tender. The Belted Galloway Beef is a risk because it's for two. The filet is absolute perfection, and just when you think it can't get better, they add a silver-dollar of bone marrow. The short rib is melt-in-your-mouth. I never knew short rib could be so good. Next, a Passion Fruit Mousse palate-cleaner and some fried donuts. Then the real dessert, work-of-art Raspberry Tart with so much amazing sorbet and a Brown Sugar Tart with a fantastic ginger ice cream. Post-dessert, they have Juniper Caramel Sticks that make you feel less grossly full and of course, chocolate truffles. If this is lunch, I MUST return for dinner. The Ledbury is among the best meals I've had in London, and it ranks among my top ten ever. I've had plenty of fine dining all around the world, but The Ledbury is in a league of its own!

r8h6N5yiq_ThHZZBKtq5Mw.text: This being one of the top restaurants in the world, we had to try it and it def did not disappoint. It is exactly what you come to expect with the Michelin rated restaurant - white glove service, extremely well though out curated food, the best of the best,  and with stunningly simple Decor and atmosphere. Prior to our arrival, when we made reservations we told them about our dietary restrictions and allergies which this restaurant curated to perfection. There was fresh baked gluten-free bread and entire four course vegan meal including but not limited to a vegan gluten-free ice cream and chocolate mousse which was one of the best hands down that I've had to date, around the world. Each plate was so uniquely different than the rest and even my husband opted to do the vegan meal because of the amazing descriptions listed on the menu. It seemed so enticing and appetizing that this was just the way to go. For a carnivore to enjoy a vegan meal, it takes a lot and this place did not disappoint. It did just that. If you are in the London area, this restaurant is not to be missed. One of the most amazing Michelin rated meals I've had and I highly recommend to anyone with any kind of dietary restriction to try this place. It was truly a magnificent birthday and they made this meal such a special meal and made us feel like we were the only people in the restaurant even though every table in the restaurant was full.

qjpVpfP8_VGiMxEdKHE9DQ.text: What a major disappointment. I went because of their reputation (2 Michelin stars, 50 Best Restaurant list) and the hype is not deserved, at least from my experience. Most of the dishes I had were bland and uneventful. I honestly didn't see any special care given to the food/service/ambiance compared to almost every other fine dinning experience I have had. The photos on Yelp did not represent anything like the meal I had (which was the tasting menu).The main server I had was nice, but there was another employee who had attitude, which made the dinner less comfortable. I was seated right by the entrance and had a nice view all evening of the servers and workers talking/preparing to serve other tables. It was not a relaxing environment. I also left the restaurant hungry, and literally went to a shawarma place in Kensington afterwards. The management should understand that some customers make sacrifices to enjoy a special meal here, at a steep cost. The food and the service felt perfunctory, it was quite disappointing.

W1t3Sp54y58y-vMfa7XCaw.text: The Ledbury is well known as of the best restaurants in London. With two Michelin Stars and an ever-changing tasting menu, this is a world class establishment with a wonderfully unpretentious ambience. No dress code, and a staff that are as genuinely friendly as they are highly trained. Reservations as far in advance as possible are suggested, as their books fill up quickly. We were lucky to secure a table for two just a few days in advance, thanks to their lovely reservations staff.Upon arrival, we were greeted warmly and seated at a table with a great view of their gorgeous dining room. Romantic soft lighting, high ceilings, and elegant, timeless decor. Luxurious without trying too hard. The wine list was abundant and curated, offering an impressive selection of bottles I had never seen before. The staff sommelier was highly knowledgeable, and recommended a Pinot Noir that we enjoyed. My boyfriend and I each decided to have the tasting menu, which I strongly suggest. They offer a fully vegetarian version for £140 per person (as opposed to the £150 pp for the standard menu). The first few courses were not on the menu-I soon discovered that this tasting menu features several mini courses between the actual courses. The first bites that came out set the tone for an incredible meal-savory tartlets served on a warm stone, elegant canapés filled with vegetable purée. As each course was brought out, our waiter briefly explained the ingredients and preparation. The meal was not only beautifully prepared and plated, but artfully choreographed.My favorite of the main courses was the White Aubergine Dusted with Olive and Black Tea. The tender eggplant fully absorbed the richly tangy marinade. The two herb infused sauces draped alongside were complex and played well together. I savored this dish, attempting to decipher the ingredients. The Hen Of The Woods mushroom was a close second. Roasted with rosemary, and beautifully presented by the chef, the multidimensional earthy flavors were exquisite. While these courses stood out, all of the others were fantastic as well, ranking among the best dishes I have ever eaten. Do not skip dessert. The dessert (and the pre-dessert) blew us away. Served atop a plate of juniper berries were two delicate rolled cookies filled with a spicy and sweet juniper and ginger sugar that melted in our mouths. Alongside were the most decadent chocolate truffles I have ever enjoyed. The main dessert course, Brown Sugar Tart with Stem Ginger Ice Cream was equally impressive. The wafer thin maple scented tart was filled with a creamy gingerbread spiced mousse, served with poached grapes and a decadent fresh ginger ice cream. Just incredible.I cannot say enough good things about The Ledbury-they deserve more than 5 stars. The tasting menu was not only an outstanding meal, but an experience that my boyfriend and I will not forget. I look forward to returning.

QMS5ffsdako2n09hAZNyYw.text: Food is my thing.  I wish it were yarn or sandy white beaches, but no - my thing is food.  Given the hype, I was anxious to try this place and luck have it, I was able to secure a reservation a month in advance. I've eaten at a few Michelin star restaurants in the US and was excited to try one in the UK.  Our reservation was for 8pm on a Wednesday night.  We were there for a total of 4.25 hours.  Each minute totally worth the 1000 pounds that we paid.First of all - the goat cheese butter was to die for as was their fresh bread to schmear it on. Part of the tasting: Round little balls filled with venison and juice Lobster meat with basil sorbet and pea tendrils Hen of the woods laying across smoldering rosemary This is just a sample of what we ate that night.  We finished it off with a cheese supplement followed by dessert.  Given the opportunity, I would go back without hesitation.

The interior décor was elegantly trendy; lighting was perfect; service was impeccable but the food did not have the "wow" factor. The wine pairing was impressive; matching with the dishes like an old married couple.  All dishes were tasty and well executed, but they were not able to "sing" in my mouth. It was a bit disappointing.

PxmI5xXJNgviejKdeTyJxw.text: Tied with Dinner by Heston Blumenthal as my top Michelin dining experience in London, The Ledbury serves a phenomenal tasting menu. My friends and I were here for over 4 hours and not a single dull minute passed by. Time seemed to fly as we savored every single bite of every single course. Yes, the food was that good. qQTBcseWmdEdR8-E1LlnKg.text: The Ledbury is a two Michelin Star restaurant in Notting Hill.  It is also ranked one of the best restaurant in the world. The decor is modern and chic - without being stuffy or pretentious. The atmosphere is relaxed. The service is attentive, professional and world class. The chef tasting menu is the way to go - it is an incredible experience. Each course was delicately prepared and displayed imagination and innovation in the culinary arts. There was a sophistication to the dishes. One of my favourite dishes was the Lebury's signature dish where the lobster meat was wrapped with shiitake mushrooms. The textures and flavours were an explosion of the senses. I would highly recommend that you give Ledbury a try. For a Michelin Star restaurant, the prices were on par with other Michelin Star restaurants. Make sure you make a reservation well in advance.

wD6pf364CCbQvUlwRDoR7g.text: It was a pretty good place.This is not just a restaurant; it is an excellent place to take you to a gastronomic journey. There are details in this restaurant which make the place stick miles above the rest.Filtered water instead of bottled,Very tasty bread baked especially for the restaurant,Butter with or without salt,Excellent food, meticulously prepared, excellent service from very well dressed staff who are there to ensure you have a great time.You have to try it at least once.

SvXvJGHj4raLoSJlL35RTQ.text: Our favorite meal in London, and one of our favorites anywhere. The Ledbury is a real class act. From service, to the incredibly composed dishes, to the full arc of the tasting menu...if you have one special meal planned for your visit to London, the Ledbury should be it.Disappointed that we couldn't get a dinner reservation for our visit, we were so thrilled that they offered the full tasting menu at lunch (in addition to the set lunch and the 4 course lunch menu). We've often regretted choosing a tasting menu in the past (there's always a flag in the progression that makes you feel as if you should have chosen otherwise), but the Ledbury's menu absolutely lived up to our expectations. From the small bites at the start, through the ridiculously awesome egg/white truffle dish, to the beautiful brown sugar tart, and even the incredible petit fours...this meal was tops from start to finish.A truly world class restaurant that exceeded our (very high) expectations.

3hOi3accXoyvNvc8sDsi3A.text: I've been meaning to try this Michelin-starred restaurant for a long time but have never been able to snatch a reservation in any of my typically-short trips to London.Last night, a good friend of mine managed to get a table for two -- I was very excited to finally experience the Ledbury.Sadly, the hype did nothing but set me up for disappointment.  Don't get me wrong, there were a couple of amazing dishes (Bantam's Egg -- I mean, how can you go wrong with truffles?!, and the Oyster dish).  But that was pretty much it.  Both of my fish dishes were bland and forgettable... and the "pallet cleanser" served after dinner / before dessert was too sweet / not tart enough to do any pallet cleansing in my mind.To top it off, as we just started digging into dessert, the waiter came over and plopped the check on our table.  2 minutes later, another waiter came over with the credit card machine (we were still eating!!!). What kind of posh restaurant does this?  Certainly left a bad taste in mouth.

CwEliLSwvUPGhAj1sturrw.text: DO NOT MAKE A RESERVATION!! If you cancel, they charge you hundreds of dollars, even if you cancel in advance. BEWARE!!There are lots of great restaurants in London. Avoid this one or you could be sorry you even thought about it. I don't care how good the food is, they cheat you.

-KcLjQrOTsoeMidr1axPZw.text: An incredible meal. Everything from the amuse bouche to the final dessert wine was perfection. The service was impeccable as well. An all-around excellent dining experience. We travel with our kids 11 and 14. We love trying all kinds of dining experiences. Our 11 year-old daughter, who's not the most adventuresome eater loved every dish. She also had some amazing insight into the dishes. We'll turn her into a foodie yet. Five stars are hard to come by in my book. The Ledbury definitely deserves this designation plus a revisit. Bravo.

8OwWvWjwvHrWHD4ghLssGQ.text: One of my bucket list items was to eat at a Michelin star rated restaurant. Who would have thought I would have been lucky enough to eat at a 2 Michelin star one like The Ledbury. This dining experience was beyond phenomenal. We made the reservation in November for January 1st. As you could imagine, I sat excited for two months. When we got there it was beautifully decorated. Our coats were taken and my purse was hung. We were seated with the chairs pulled out for us, truly magical.The tasting menu was unique and I loved everything I tried from start to finish. The amazing thing about a tasting menu is that you actually end up being so full. Everything was to die for.Each person came over to ask how everything was and many made conversation about where we were from and what we were doing in London. Definitely a great experience and hopefully not a once in a lifetime one. I will be back!

V882rg_jAJEnGG1bTjmjjQ.text: The Ledbury's service was excellent and food was so good. We have tried a few tasting menus in our Europe trip before The Ledbury, and it one of our favorite meals in Europe. It is a special place with special meal for you if your visit to London. Everything is great, 100% worth to try. We definitely will be back if we visit London.

h7T6Cq-WQj-byfxiMuTXQw.text: I picked this as our one fancy meal for our trip in London and I'm so glad I did! We had a great time enjoying delicious food. My favorite dish here (that I still remember months later) was a green bean salad with peaches, nuts, and powdered foie gras sprinkled on top. I've never had foie gras powdered and it was shockingly delicious. I had a roasted cauliflower (the visual presentation almost made it look too good to eat!) and a perfectly cooked fish. For dessert, I had a strawberry lavender tart that was fantastic too. The BF was happy with his pork and chocolate dessert. Service was great and we walked around the charming neighborhood streets after our meal to digest!

jP86szeR9LL_tMiTQab1VA.text: I have been to The Ledbury about 6 times now and it is hands down the best restaurant in London.  Food does not get better than this.I've been to Ramsay, Fat Duck and others and I would choose this place anytime.I went this past Monday and had (as always) the tasting menu. Our meal started with a thin homemade mille feuille (I think was the term for it), with foie gras.  Delicious flavours and perfectly seasoned.The Ceviche of Hand Dived Scallops with Seaweed and Herb Oil,Kohlrabi and Frozen Horseradish was delicately presented and just an incredible combination of flavours.This was followed by "Risotto" of Squid with Pine Nuts, Sherry and Cauliflower.  Incredibly, the risotto was actually made from thinly cut squid!  the cauliflower was like shaved parmasan cheese.  Very creative and beautiful.We were then brought out Celeriac Baked in Ash with Hazelnuts and a Kromeski of Wild Boar.  The ash was brought out before which is like a cocoon that cooks the celeraic for 24 hours.  Another triumph.Then came out Roast Cod with Grilled Leeks, Hand Rolled Macaroniand Truffle Purée.  Again incredible and great attention to detail down to the homemade macaroni.  This was followed by Pyrenean Milk Fed Lamb with Baked Jerusalem Artichokes and Winter Savory Milk.  By this point I was starting to get full but still managed to wipe every last globule off my plate with bread!Dessert was  a beautiful and refreshing jelly (I can't remember what it was).I didn't know such flavour combinations could exist until I went to the Ledbury.  How on earth a chef can think up such incredible dishes is beyond me and Brett Graham is truly an artist.This restaurant deserves more Michelin Stars!**UPDATE:  As of January 2010, The Ledbury was awarded a second Michelin Star.  Congrats and well deserved.

hZOuTT2ky2PXaPpfHAyvVQ.text: Wow! Just wow!! You expect that a two Michelin star restaurant is good, but what I didn't see coming was that as soon as the extremely professional staff had seen that that we were a "light" group and just there to have a good time, they started playing on the jokes and being a little more loose - but always staying well on the professional side. Very, very impressive balance that just perfected the night. Wow!

62wI1xDRnbJxBfZg-crjgg.text: For photos, see Greedy Diva @ greedydiva.blogspot.com/…  Within a few weeks after we first moved to London 4 years ago, The Peanut Gallery was researching London restaurants for my birthday dinner. The man does not hold back when it comes to restaurant research, and he hit on a place in Notting Hill that sounded like the goods. And so it was that The Ledbury set my benchmark for London fine dining. It's still my favourite place for a posh lunch or dinner. I've been back twice since - once with friends for the great value set price lunch (at £33.50 for 3 courses) - a terrific way to experience the brilliance while the sun flirts in through the huge surrounding windows. The second revisit was just last week to catch up over dinner with Aussie food blogging friends, Gourmet Chick, Catty and Vintage Macaroon as well as the lovely Claire from Australian wine maker, d'Arenberg. What better place to meet than over the fine food of Australian head chef, Brett Graham, drinking terrific Australian wines kindly contributed by D'Arenberg (thanks Claire) and Katnook Estate (thanks Jo). Jo (who couldn't join us in the end) made contact with Brett Graham, who put together a special tasting menu for us, tweaked to match our wines. Over a bottle of champagne well chosen by the sommelier to meet our request for something reasonably light and crisp, we start with the pretty, mousse-like foie gras canape followed by the amuse bouche - a deep fried quail egg with Jerusalem artichoke puree and shaved truffles. Firm broccoli stem with natural yoghurt and tiny, sweet Falmouth Bay prawns in brown butter and vadouvan (a mixture of onions, shallots and garlic with Indian spices) is one of my favourite courses. This dish highlights the kitchen's dexterity for textures and combining vivid flavours in well balanced harmony. Basically, it's clever, and it tastes brilliant. Who knew broccoli could be this good? We drink the 2009 Katnook Estate Sauvignon Blanc from Coonawarra - a Sauv with body and lots of zesty citrus and apple. A shallow soup bowl is presented next. Across the base is a thin layer of Hampshire buffalo milk curd with uncooked French cheese, Saint-Nectaire. Small clusters of grilled onions and mushrooms are dotted around the plate. At the table, an aromatic, delicate broth of grilled onions is poured over the top and, on the side, waits a toasted brioche topped with large thin disks of earthy black truffle and puree. Again, there are delightfully balanced layers of flavour at work - just gorgeous. With this, we drink d'Arenberg's 2008 "The Last Ditch" Viognier from McLaren Vale. It's exactly the type of wine I love. It's been aged for 6 months in French and American oak, and has a lovely, big honey and cream character. Next up, a colourful arrangement of root vegetables, a nutty, sweet and earthy mix, baked in salt and clay with roasting juices, hazelnuts and Lardo di Colonnata (the silky pork fat from pigs having spent their lives feasting on acorns and chestnuts in Tuscany). Oh my. What better way to turn vegetables into pure, indulgent gluttony? Our accompanying 2005 Katnook Estate Cabernet Sauvignon has rich fruit and tannin, but is light enough so as not to overpower this dish. A plump, moist fillet of roast cod glistens beside a mellow truffle puree, cauliflower, parmesan gnocchi and, for some extra umami, sea vegetables. Again, it looks pretty and it's a perfectly executed delight to eat. Finally, the loin of roe deer is baked in Douglas fir (coniferous tree) with beetroot and malt. There's an accompanying venison sausage, which is rich and gamey. The loin is tender and, although I think it lacks some flavour, it's topped with an oozy blob of rich marrow which adds depth. We accompany it with the 2002 d'Arenberg "The Dead Arm" Shiraz. This is a big, gutsy Aussie Shiraz, with intense fruit, chocolate and spice. It's a gorgeous match for our rich, autumnal game dish. Before dessert, we cleanse the palate (ok, any excuse) with a tart passion fruit concoction in a shot glass, before finishing with a fantastic, sweet brown sugar tart. It looks like a long slab of foie gras and, praise the lord, is almost as rich. It comes with muscat grapes and a stem ginger ice-cream. Coffees and teas at the end are matched with our choice from a delicious selection of jellies, merigues, macaroons and chocolates. Although we didn't try it, the cheese trolley - or, more accurately, the smell of the cheese trolley - deserves a mention. Fantastic. When it moves about the room, it's like you just wandered into the cheese room at La Fromagerie with your nostrils fully flared. Save room. Service was, as always, professional, knowledgeable and friendly without a shred of stuffiness or irritating fuss. Brett Graham wasn't in the kitchen on the night we ate (he was shooting in Scotland), and so our fantastic meal only goes to show what an all round strong

JLsgySB5XecBzyiEoJ-V3w.text: I know Michelin star isn't everything but this two Michelin starred restaurant is worthy of 3 in my opinion. The best two starred for sure. I ordered chef's tasting menu.Food pace was bit rushed but it was ok because the food was so nice I wanted them keep coming. It was very nice from the bread selection. The ham brioche is like from heaven.  Bit of fish, bit of meat, all tasted good and perfectly cooked.Service was amazing and offered to call a taxi afterward. You can also enjoy a little bit of walking in the nice neighbourhood of Notting Hill.

ji9VU6dgeJdfyQndTMtebA.text: We went to the Ledbury for their Sunday lunch. All I can say is the food was incredible. Our waiter did a nice job making recommendations of dishes that were unique yet delicious. My wife is vegetarian and they had a separate vegetarian menu. The desserts were incredible. They ended up giving us three desserts all of which were incredible. The sommelier was helpful in selecting wine for us. Everyone of their staff was very friendly and attentive to our needs. I would highly recommend the ledbury for a special meal.

Uas_ERZjmH737JKf4lTJ9Q.text: Best lunch of 2010. By miles. Can't wait to go back.

e4qiwHEyIj5GaRK2YXVSog.text: The Ledbury is a little one Michelin star oasis of sublime French cooking in the heart of Notting Hill. Westbourne Grove is a little treasure trove of wonderful food experiences but the Ledbury is a venue offering a slightly more upmarket experience. I was lucky to be taken there for a belated birthday meal by some good friends from medical school.The restaurant website gives a good idea of the dishes - classical French tradition married to some modern ideas and presentation. The staff were efficient and friendly and people were dressed in a mixture of casual and more formal wear.We decided on the tasting menu which had some unusual dishes on it as well as some old favourites.1. The amuse of tomato essence was an excellent palate cleanser and got the gastric juices going nicely.2. The oily flame grilled mackarel and smoked eel were nicely evened out by the mustard dressing that was sweet, slightly acidic with a little mustard heat to cut through all the richness. A little nasturtium reflected the current trend to decorate plates with flowers.3. The most unusual sounding dish of the day was the celeriac baked whole in ash - this was brought whole to the table to show us before it was sliced. I can see why this was done because the once presented on the plate with the hazelnuts, wood sorrel and pork kromeski, it was so wonderfully tasty and so savoury that I would never have guessed that it was celeriac. An amazing dish in its concept and execution and exactly the reason I dine at Michelin star establishments - they have some dishes that I can't even conceive in my wildest dreams let alone cook them.4. Foie gras :-)  How can it ever go wrong? :-)  I prefer mine seared but this was served as a wonderfully rich torchon.5. Brill done in a classical meuniere with some creamed potatoes, mussels and broccoli in a lovely light seafood jus.6. The next unusual dish was muntjac. We had to ask the waiter what this was and it's deer. We were served best end of muntjac baked in hay served with root vegetables, pear and liquorice. I love pear and I love game but would never have put them together. Another genius moment.7. Pre dessert of nice light sorbet.8. Brown sugar tart which was yummy, served with Muscat grapes, white raisin ice cream and vin cotto.The quality of the meal was reflected in the fact that 4 hours just flew by and we had to run to catch our last Tube! A wonderful place for a special occasion.

nPq34ZQ9zvOX0ntuJvYGcQ.text: Love the dining room, warm and relaxed but still classy. The food I had was delicious without exception, especially the passion fruit soufflé, but possibly only suitable for people who like rich food. Up until I finished my dessert it was a 5 star experience but then we were seemingly forgotten. We sat with empty plates in front of us for far too long and eventually had to flag down a waiter, might be a petty thing but this is a small dining room with highly trained staff. Agonised whether this knocked one or two stars off but for the price I just expected better.

-jc8BCWFVgsnE0Xyt9P_KQ.text: first time for me at Ledbury, i really liked. Service was great, food was nice, its 2 michelin star, but i expected more attention on the details, food was good, wine was ok,we just miss a bit information about dishes.so i would recommend, and planing to back next moth! good luck =]

nBWJBDWCzX5ULCG9luKanA.text: great meal, great service, looking forard to finding reason to return.

8yJnw0waAGYsuohKPqif4g.text: Aussie chef Brett Graham is a genius and the service at The Ledbury is the best I have had, anywhere.Highlights were the Celeriac Baked in Ash and the amuse bouche including a beetroot merang.We ate there when Brett had just one star... great to see he now has his second!

27taz1d8nyyRf2vXz9xnqA.text: This was our first dining experience on our London visit this summer and it could not have been better. We ordered the tasting menu with the wine parings. The food and wine were fabulous and the service was even better. Just 10 days after we had dined there, I opened the paper to read about how the staff went above and beyond the call of duty, protecting their customers during the recent rioting break in at the restaurant.  I read how the staff had fought off those rioting thugs with rolling pins, fry baskets and various other kitchen instruments, after they had broken into the restaurant and were threatening and attempting to rob their customers. The staff, in my opinion are all heroes. It is a true testament of the high quality and high standards of the employees and management of this business.

7gEGa3_JShVQ0Jid3eLvFQ.text: first learned of Ledbury after reading accounts of staff defending it's patrons from hooligans in the 2011 riots. stars just for that, a recent meal here now tops my London "best of" list. offerings in the £35 summer set menu were clever and delicious, lunch generous by any stretch: amuse, wicked bacon-onion brioche, sorbet and petit four also served. Go, food is brilliant, mad to miss out. telegraph.co.uk/news/ukn…

47jFBJz8jq9Z__QWO8YlHA.text: Perfection, the best place in London to celebrate a special occasion, in our case my daughter's birthday. We all had the tasting menu, which is £105 a head plus service, but every single course, eight in all, was sensational, in quality, presentation and flavour. Even the breads were wonderful. This has got to be as good as it gets in London at present. The service is superb also, smooth and professional, with every course described for you when it has been served. I nearly had to increase my limit on my Amex card to encompass the bill, but it was absolutely worth it. Lucky London that Brett Graham abandoned Australia to come here.

fJ1jbxo_FecgHdTXz-1Cvw.text: Notting Hill is a great location, as it is a trendy, stylish area, with a vibrant and sophisticated atmosphere.If you love French cuisine, then you must try The Ledbury, its the ultimate dining experience, the staff are formal, kind, respectful and knowledgeable, the interior is beautiful, formal, yet welcoming and classy.Got familiar with dishes that I'd never thought I will try before, was really impressed with the presentation, let alone the taste. Superb food and a great evening, highly recommend.

n4-YpE0JokN8ArAwo3mFHA.text: Best meal we had in london, over the square or murano....top to bottom, great service, the food was transcendent, it all worked. this is a very very special place

Jm9COp_GYqZLXr1RXX32fQ.text: I was recently introduced to this 2 Michelin starred chi chi restaurant in Notting Hill, which has always been my go to list and has rapidly become one of my top 5 restaurants ever. Most 2 michelin star restaurants are full of pomp and ceremony and are often not a relaxing affair, unlike this beauty in a leafy upmarket st in West London. The restaurant is intimate but buzzy at the same time and is probably a reflection of its' clientele (the well heeled, i spotted a Roksanda Ilinic dress walking around!). The service is excellent. Finally and most importantly it is all about the food here. The food has an Antipodean influence and delivers big flavours subtly. At the weekend , you are forced to eat the tasting menu (only a la carte on the weekdays), which would be my only grumble, i like having a choice. However, the tasting menu blew me away from the beginning with the oh so moreish bacon brioche. The flame grilled mackerel was a crispy, salty morsel of extreme delight ( i don't normally like mackerel). Course after course came in just the right quantities and hit big time taste sensation levels (i felt like shouting bingo at each course.). I cannot fault the meal or the evening, einfach klasse. Not cheap but worth every pound and the distance. I so envy West Londoners who have this gastronomic haven on their doorstep. (monikasays.com )

qVOaFcSLqF2wAW6ARJ6ZkQ.text: please also seehungryinlondon.com/2010/…  A special restaurant for special occasions I was very excited to finally dine at The Ledbury in Notting Hill. (I took RS there for his birthday, lucky guy!) The chef Brett Graham is only 30 years old and has accomplished 2 Michelin stars for his restaurant (for a more detailed description of the chef's CV and some beautiful pictures of the food at the Ledbury I refer you to the excellent post by Cheese and Biscuits). The food is 'modern French' with some interesting twists, I particularly enjoyed the play with unusual flavours which you kind of think can't work together and can't help but order out of curiosity: let me guarantee you however, they do work very well indeed! The atmosphere is exactly right for a special and/or romantic date: it does feel pleasantly posh without being overly pretentious, tables are far enough apart to feel private and to not overhear other peoples conversations and waiters are hoovering around reading your thoughts before you even know you had them without being intrusive. They do have a fair share of French waiters which admittedly adds to the romantic atmosphere. However, I found it impossible to understand their accent, therefore I have missed most of the ingredients in the amuse bouches. They were lovely anyway :) The a la carte menu costs 65 pounds for 3 courses while the tasting menu is 75 pounds. This is really not cheap  you do get something for your money though  it feels like a tasting menu even with having only the 3 courses as you get 2 additional amuse bouches as a starter, a pre-dessert and even some chocolate at the very end (before you finally role out the door). We started with Ceviche of Scallops with Kohlrabi and Frozen Horseradish. An interesting looking plate of food reminiscent of a winter wonderland but boy was it good! The frozen horseradish slowly melted onto the thinly sliced scallops while releasing its flavours. Food like this is fun! The Grilled Mackerel with Cucumber did not quite live up to the grand expectations: the mackerel was slightly dry and for me it was ok rather then wow. Also with the mains there was one clear winner: the Lamb with Miso Aubergine. The lamb was so tender and cooked to perfection in a lovely sauce that made you want to lick the plate (I doubt this would have made me many friends there though). And the aubergine!! Soft and with a sweet miso flavour it was absolutely delicious. For me less convincing was the Poached John Dory with Blood Orange, Crab and Asparagus. There was nothing obviously wrong with it, a nice plate of food, but it was slightly one-dimensional and something seemed to be lacking. Then came my favourite amuse bouche to clean our palate  panna cotta with peach ice cream was a dream and much too small.. As dessert I opted for the Eucalyptus and Gingerbread Souffle with Thyme Ice Cream. The opinion on the dessert was not unanimous: I thought it was perfect. The delicious thyme ice cream melted into the perfect fluffy souffle rich in vanilla/gingerbread flavour with just the slightest hint of eucalyptus. RS said it tastes soapy. Good, so there was more for me! The Cheese Platter was generous: 4 cheeses chosen for us by the French cheese waiter (3 of which we really liked) came with lovely fresh, still warm fruit bread. Cave: they served us the wrong bottle of wine in the beginning (more expensive, surprise surprise!)  gladly we realised because this would have been an even bigger disaster for my finances However, to make up for it, they invited us to a half glass of very nice French white wine. I forgive easily We had a perfect evening but unfortunately The Ledbury is a challenge for your bank account. However, despair not, they serve an incredibly bargain lunch menu for 40 pounds. For special occasion food I recommend also Launceston Place in South Kensington: I found the food there comparable in taste and quality while their 3 course evening menu is only 45 pounds

46G2Z0ut56PvUHG818xIvQ.text: We went to The Ledbury in Notting Hill around New Year's Eve and to sum it up: It was absolutely stunning! The Michelin Star is well deserved, with the restaurant providing a small number of maybe a dozen well-sized tables, plenty of space, a lovely decoration and atmosphere, a formidable cuisine and an absolutely delightful staff. We laid our evening's fate into the hands of the chef and decided on the Tasting Menu, a seasonally changing menu with around eight or nine set courses and a suiting selection of wines, providing plenty of variation; especially compared to an usual three-coursed menu. And there truly aren't enough words to describe just how wonderful the menu was. Each and every dish was beautifully arranged, perfectly seasoned, very creative and so well prepared and full of detail, that it was almost a culinary adventure in itself. The staff was just as high-classed as the cuisine: very warm, highly professional, friendly, attentive and polite, there was always someone there to provide us with everything we needed at any given moment. From the elaborate explanation of every course, wine and cheese to little details like the napkins, which were newly folded every time a guest went to the bathroom, the service was truly impeccable. We really felt in good hands and that everyone at The Ledbury wanted us to enjoy our stay as much as possible - and we certainly did. At £108.00 (including wine) per person, the Tasting Menu certainly wasn't cheap, but definitely worth every penny; especially considering the wide variety of masterfully prepared dishes and the brilliant choice of wines. Our mandatory (sparkling) water was even surprisingly cheap, at about £4.00 per bottle, so that there was no necessity to even consider ordering tap water at all. We really cannot wait to visit The Ledbury again. It was a perfect dinner.

qak7aO4m1Ea1hOUTheHDmg.text: 2 Michelin Star RatedI didn't really enjoy the food at this restaurant very much.Scallops - really dislikedTomato with goat cheese - loved! Best tomato dish I've hadFoie gras - failMackerel - Really crisp and had so much flavor. I will definitely be ordering more mackerel in the future.Cod - mehLamb - goodPre Dessert was ice cream - very boringDessert was something weird like olive oil ice cream mixed with other stuff. - surprisingly good and came with a side of freshly baked beignets.anitaeat.com

V-OBxqzwzLyaETVcY2Q-rg.text: This is absolutely the best meal I have ever tasted!  I enjoyed a lovely dinner with 2 of my friends from the States.  This was our first meal on our trip to London and I must say we were very impressed!  The service was impeccable.  The lamb, prepared two ways was phenomenal.  The frog leg beignets melted in my mouth!  E verything was seasoned perfectly!  The desserts we shared were delicious!  Everything was presented beautifully and each time the servers/runners brought a dish to the table they explained the entire plate.  This two hour dining experience is something I will never forget!  Especially the beautiful quail egg in haystack with flowers!  Totally delish times 1000!
