MLuZS2llYIdcWmBKBl2EnA.text: Coming from NY, the Ledbury did not disappoint! We did the tasting and everything tasted delicious and service was up to par! Had a wonderful experience!

bTYaw0PMiTZ-a2R7YcZThQ.text: I had a number of friends telling me to dine at the Ledbury. After two months on the waiting list I finally managed to dine there. I went large - the tasting menu. This comprised of 9 different plates all of which were superbly executed. First up was the amuse bouche - a lovely breaded quail's egg with what I think was truffle. A taste sensation. It got even better with the second dish - Chantilly of Oysters, with a tartar of oyster, horseradish and dill - The dish was served in a martini glass and was for me the highlight of the meal. It was like being kissed by a sea monster!Next was a flame grilled mackerel with smoked eel, which came with a lovely celtic mustardFollowing that was Scallops with Fennel, bergamot, and liquorice and good combination of flavours.Next up was Buffalo milk curd, with a thin consume sauce poured over it. Personally speaking this would not be my choice, although it was perfectly executed and had an interest fusion of flavours.This was swiftly followed by celeriac baked in ash, with boar and hazelnuts another highlight. The earthy celeriac worked well with the sweet hazelnut. Another highlight of the meal.The next dish was a fillet of beef that you could tell had been aged for the required length of time. It was like cutting through butter with a hot knife.Having got over the hump of the meal, we had a pre-dessert of what was coconut milk with (I think) a passionfruit jelly.But the next highlight was the mille feuille with rhubarb and clementine leaf ice cream. The ice cream was sensational and unlike anything I've ever tasted. My third highlight of the evening.All in all every meal was perfectly executed and superb. The staff very attentive but without being over bearing. It's worth saying that our sommelier was excellent all evening, giving a passionate account of each wine that I tasted.Expensive yes, but worth every penny.

zwhhhr7pORtiK2IoXWNqUw.text: The food is very good. They also offer lovely mock tails for those who don't want alcohol.On the weekends they only offer a choice of two tasting menus for dinner. This obviously makes their job simple. I think a very good kitchen should be up to the challenge of offering diners a proper choice of either a tasting menu or a regular dinner menu. It is for this reason that I deducted a star.Another reason is value for money.Too expensive.

_a3AHp4pG2HsDlH4TK-Q9A.text: Among the best in London and the UK. We had a bottle of Felton Road Block 5. Among my favorite Pinots but not found very often in UK or US. Sommelier very good and interesting.  Nice relaxed service. Along with the Square they have a very enjoyable British take on French cooking using the best ingredients. A winning approach to luxury dining

gwKklA65H27Pcicw20bLFw.text: Wonderful.  Belongs in the Top 10 San Pellegrino rather than Blumenthal.  The tasting menu was great, the service superb and the venue stately and soothing.  We even got a tour of the kitchen and spoke with the Chef.  A very nice end to a wonderful evening.  It is a must visit in London.

cpCuYkzt6kXWqwZ2HdKfnQ.text: Truly stunning food with great service. Best meal I've had in London

Z2Ki-mgzzMLuk5bx917kiQ.text: *Dine At the Best, Skip the Rest*Second time dining here was earlier this month (7Aug2012).  Previous visit was 2 years prior.  Both times were for dinner.  One of my 2 favorite restaurants on the planet (other is Masa's in San Francisco).  My wife and I are spoiled, so we've been fortunate to dine at many superior restaurants.  The gems stand out and are unforgettable.There are already scads of reviews that sing the praises of this restaurant, so scroll through them for more details.The food is of the highest quality in every respect, the menu choices are plentiful, and the wine list is extensive, as are the dessert and cheese offerings.  Everything is delish delish delish.  On top of that the service is impeccable.  Not intrusive.  Your conversations are not interrupted.  But if you want some advice about the wine or the cheese, for example, you'll get A+ assistance.  Pleasant and relaxing in every respect.It's all too rare that highly praised restaurants live up to that praise.  The Ledbury does, and it's a wonderful dining experience.  Congratulations to the staff for such a great job.

kUUcaCh4P7dsbbF677MKQA.text: Weird place... nice food.. bad lighting very raw and white.. strange crowd (... like they came on coaches, or won a raffle or something - not very London??) everyone stared when my very normal gay friends had a quick snog and it was quick ... I felt like we were in some rural gastro pub. The food was nice, the staff was affected, very odd all round, especially for Notting Hill. Some food was great the wine was lovely- but i have never been so distracted by my fellow diners in my life ... odd ....I felt like staring back but am way too polite...maybe it gets great reviews and people save up to come here or something ?

Oxq80EsDsm03KQUHvHYkmg.text: lovely restaurant and surprisingly small for the reputation.  -they could be bigger if they wanted but i think the atmosphere for a large, spacious living room with big windows and high ceilings felt right.the menu was inventive...the heirloom tomatoes were delicious, scallops, grouse and suckling pig were really good.  i think we just prefer more simple presentation and slightly more careful on repeat ingredients (or presentation), especially if they're strong...like beetroot.service was immaculate.  sommelier who knows the range so if you're feeling old school or funky, he knows it.  servers were friendly, knowledgeable about the menu and ingredients and very prompt.

Rev9kKh4YIMxfNMD1V4kjA.text: Best meal of my life, no question.You know something good is going on when each course of your 7-course tasting menu alternately leaves you speechless and giggling. I can't imagine a more perfectly executed dinner, from the insanely delicious food to the attentive but not cloying service to the elegant but relaxed atmosphere, The Ledbury was PERFECT.Go.  Eat beans on toast for a month so that you can afford it. Seriously, it's worth it.  Just go.  Absolutely amazing, and worth every stinking penny.

_vx7Ox9WkTW2v-lY3FCgEQ.text: Fantastic. Inventive menu and the best service. I've gone three times and have always left extremely happy. Last time I was there I got a paper cut and they even brought me a bandage.

WcUz6h0Aj4PHhnQV37Qt0g.text: Overall, an excellent experience. We decided to give this place a try so that we could determine whether this place is worthy of two Michelin stars. Well, it is, no question about it. From the hot and fresh bread (three kinds), the foie gras amuse bouche, through the mackerel, monkfish, and bone marrow-topped deer loin, this tasting menu was exceptionally palatable. The only drawback was that one of the servers seemed to have been afflicted with a pungent body odour, but what can you do? As for pricing, let's just say that considering the quality of the food, it's a great value.

55aayMTdN_mNdWSw-bxNNw.text: I was thoroughly impressed by this place. It certainly earns its 2 Michelin stars. I found the deer entree to be simply outstanding, and the mackerel a very solid appetizer. For dessert, my mille-feuille was ok... others had passion fruit souffle that was out of this world. The price fixe menu was £80 a person, a fairly reasonable price for a restaurant of this caliber. The atmosphere is classy but not stuffy, an interesting balance. We had 2 amuse bouches! One before the appetizer, and one before dessert.

3Q5zTJqUpcj678NPOUYc1A.text: I enjoyed the food very much but it was unmemorable. To read the complete review, please go to chopstix2steaknives.blog…

zGsLqs8a0oKEe52PWjjFHg.text: Yesterday I had dinner here with my parents. They were visiting and I decided they deserve an amazing evening. We had some wine, salad and were truly impressed from the main courses. The food was delicious and freshly prepared. Kudos to the chef.

XleEjqXWhBl0wjQlLgtZSw.text: Is it a bit sad that the tasting menu at the Ledbury was one of the highlights of 2010, culinary or otherwise, for me? Either way, the whole evening, an anniversary treat, was an experience to remember, from start to finish. We were (naively) a bit concerned that we'd be somehow "found out" on attempting to eat in such a posh place but we needn't have worried. The décor and atmosphere were much more informal than I'd expected and the service so efficient that I couldn't believe that we weren't the only ones dining that night. I won't go into detail of the food - suffice to say that each mouthful of the tasting menu was mindblowing. The accompanying wine was a delight and the sommelier pitched his summaries just right. One of the best touches, however, was that we (apparently) had to wait a few minutes more than is usual for our pear and hazelnut dessert. So we were then brought two extra complementary puddings from the à la carte menu (brown sugar tart with stem ginger icecream - to die for - and thyme/eucalyptus soufflé). Awesome. Can't recommend it highly enough.

9G_kWajkDeV8THgV90rFjQ.text: Amazing. Breath taking. As close to perfect as it gets. It currently has 1 Star, however, trust me, a second one is on the way.My first experience with The Ledbury was a few weeks ago, on a night so filled with rain it was insane that i was on foot outside. i walked by with a friend and paused to look at the menu posted outside. the manger, a wonderful man named John, saw us and said hello, asked if we wanted to step inside for a look. hardly dressed for the venue, we shied, but he insisted. Charming and friendly, John obviously loves what he does. when he found out that my friend and i had an interest in the the culinary world, he offered to take us down to the kitchen (!!!) and meet the chef(!!!!!!). Chef Bret managed to get a few words with us between plating full service and told us to give him a shout when we came back for dinner. flash forward to the next week when we actually came in for dinner. oh. my. god. no really. every mouthful was an experience. we got the tasting menu complete with wine pairing and it was fantastic. so much food, but we could hardly resist finishing every plate. When Chef Brett found out that we were there, we came up at the end of our meal and hung out, chatting for 30 min, talking tips of the trade and fun stories of service. he gave both of us his card and said anytime he could help out with anything. i was full for 2 days. im actually going in next week to hang out for a day in the kitchen. i cant wait.

ykT_hj2RRvsOskfNTFyVJw.text: AMAZING food and excellent value on the set lunch which was £33 for 3 courses. Despite only 2 options per course, I could have easily eaten any of the dishes on the menu without any hesitation. Service was excellent too.

KYEXQkLHPJI6SSbk_z41gA.text: I am not a total foodie, but The Ledbury could tempt me to become one.I was taken as a treat on a Tuesday night by a few friends are slowing eating their way through the world's best restaurants.  They seemed to enjoy their time.I had the 9 course tasting menu with wine pairing.  The courses started getting really interesting around course 3 or 4, becoming more exotic as they progressed.  The central course was pigeon.  I never have tasted anything like this, and the wines really were great along with each course.  This was my first time doing a wine pairing where I actually "got it".  We also had a cheese course which was fun, and the cheese specialist came around and explained a bit about each option, none of which were duds in the end.  Very nice.  I wouldn't visit the Ledbury on a regular basis, but I might return again with my husband for a special treat.
